attributes.title: Taking advice from a native versus non-native accented speaker

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Taking advice from a native versus non-native accented speaker: when individuals lack feedback does accent serve as a signal for knowledge?

other.value: For exploratory purposes, we will also collect information on their perceived initial guess accuracy, perceived advisor accuracy, and perceived final guess accuracy to see if there is differences in how relatively accurate the advisor is perceived as being to the participant despite not getting feedback.

sample.value: We will collect a sample of 200 subjects (100 per accent condition).

analyses.value: We will conduct a mixed effects logistic regression examining whether subjects followed the advice or did not follow the advice of the advisor for their final answer across language conditions, controlling for whether or not subjects initially matched with the advisor as well as random effects of subject and speaker within accent conditions.

outliers.value: Subjects will be excluded if their initial response accuracy is over 3 standard deviations above the overall sample initial response accuracy, as this would suggest these subjects had far higher baseline knowledge of the correct answers than the rest of the sample and hence may not need to use the advice.

dependent.value: Key DV: The extent to which subjects agreed with the advisor for their final response, while controlling for rates at which subjects had already matched with the advisor in their initial guess.

conditions.value: Subjects will be assigned to one of two accent conditions (Accent: Native | Nonnative, between subjects). Also, within accent conditions, subjects will be assigned to one of two token speakers.

hypothesis.value:
For this study, subjects will answer 48 difficult trivia questions with four possible options, which have been pretested to be at a chance (25% accuracy) for most participants. For each question, subjects will provide an initial guess to the trivia problem (to get a measure of baseline knowledge), will hear a suggested answer provided by a native-accented or nonnative-accented advisor (who is accurate 75% of the time), and then give their final response. 

We hypothesize that individuals will be less likely to follow advice provided by a nonnative accented advisor as compared to a native accented advisor.

registration_responses.analyses: We will conduct a mixed effects logistic regression examining whether subjects followed the advice or did not follow the advice of the advisor for their final answer across language conditions, controlling for whether or not subjects initially matched with the advisor as well as random effects of subject and speaker within accent conditions.
registration_responses.outliers: Subjects will be excluded if their initial response accuracy is over 3 standard deviations above the overall sample initial response accuracy, as this would suggest these subjects had far higher baseline knowledge of the correct answers than the rest of the sample and hence may not need to use the advice.
registration_responses.dependent: Key DV: The extent to which subjects agreed with the advisor for their final response, while controlling for rates at which subjects had already matched with the advisor in their initial guess.
registration_responses.conditions: Subjects will be assigned to one of two accent conditions (Accent: Native | Nonnative, between subjects). Also, within accent conditions, subjects will be assigned to one of two token speakers.

For this study, subjects will answer 48 difficult trivia questions with four possible options, which have been pretested to be at a chance (25% accuracy) for most participants. For each question, subjects will provide an initial guess to the trivia problem (to get a measure of baseline knowledge), will hear a suggested answer provided by a native-accented or nonnative-accented advisor (who is accurate 75% of the time), and then give their final response. 

We hypothesize that individuals will be less likely to follow advice provided by a nonnative accented advisor as compared to a native accented advisor.

attributes.title: False memories and monitoring in a native or foreign language

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: False memories and monitoring in a native or foreign language: Likelihood of endorsing false information in the misinformation effect paradigm.

other.value: Prior piloting of these materials has not shown an order effect running the two video paradigms as a within subjects design. However, if we do get a significant Language x Order effect in our analyses, we will divide the sample in half and analyze only the first paradigm (thereby analyzing Language as a between subjects factor).

analyses.value: We will run an ANOVA examining the likelihood of endorsing false information as true, specifically examining the Misinformation and Control questions (since these are the key DVs of interest). Therefore, the model will examine how Language (Native | Foreign) x Question Type (Misinformation | Control) influences likelihood of selecting TRUE for the Misinformation and Control Questions, while controlling for covariates that may influence memory such as video assigned to each language (Video: Video 1 | Video 2) and narrative speaker within languages.

outliers.value: Subjects will be excluded if they report their native language as being less proficient than their foreign language. Also, prior to participating all subjects must be native Mandarin Chinese speakers who know English as a second language and are over 18 years old. This will be assessed via a prescreen before they participate in the study.

dependent.value:
The DVs of interest for this study are the 36 memory questions about each of the videos, run in the assigned language of the narrative. These questions are comprised of 4 types of questions: 

- Consistent questions: Questions in which a certain detail that was given in the narrative matches the true information of what occurred in the video (ex. in the video the robber left a black glove and the narrative says the robber left a black glove). For these questions, the possible answer is always correct so subjects should respond with TRUE. 
- Control Questions: Questions in which a certain detail was shown in the video but was not specified in the narrative (ex. in the video the robber left a black glove but in the narrative it doesn't specify what the color of the glove was). For these questions, the possible answer is always incorrect so subjects should respond with FALSE. 
- Misinformation Questions: Questions in which a certain detail that was given in the narrative does not match with the true information of what occurred in the video (ex. in the video the robber left a black glove and the narrative says the robber left a white glove). For these questions, the possible answer is always incorrect so subjects should respond with FALSE. 
- Video Only Questions: Questions in which a certain detail was never mentioned in the narrative but was shown in the video (ex. in the video the robber left a black glove and the narrative never mentions anything about a glove). For these questions, the possible answer is always correct so subjects should respond with TRUE. 

While each of these memory questions provides valuable information about how individuals remember the narrative, the key DV of interest is the likelihood of endorsing false information for the misinformation questions (selecting TRUE for the Misinformation Questions) while controlling for the baseline likelihood of endorsing false information when the false information was never specified in the narrative (selecting TRUE for the Control Questions) across language conditions (Native or Foreign).

conditions.value:
The main IV of interest is Language (Native or Foreign), which will be run as a within subjects design. However, language order will be counterbalanced across participants: half of subjects will receive the video, narrative, and memory test in their native Chinese first, and half will receive the video, narrative, and memory test in their foreign English first. 

For each video, subjects will be assigned one of two narratives about the video (Narrative Assignment: Narrative 1 | Narrative 2, between subjects). These two narratives are identical, except that the same detail that acts as false information in one narrative (ex. Narrative 1 says the robber left a white glove when in the video he left a black glove) will be unspecified in the second narrative (ex. Narrative 2 says the robber left a glove when in the video he left a black glove). Across subjects, this allows us to examine the likelihood of endorsing false information specified in the narrative (Misinformation Questions) while comparing it to the likelihood of endorsing the same false information when it was not specified in the narrative (Control Questions).

hypothesis.value:
For bilinguals, individuals often receive information in their native or foreign language. The goal of this project is to examine the likelihood that individuals will endorse remembering false information, using the misinformation effect paradigm. In this paradigm, subjects will watch two silent videos, and then receive a narrative about each which contains false details about the prior video (one in their native Chinese; one in their foreign English: each narrative will be assigned one of six native speakers within each language (6 Chinese, 6 English: 12 speakers total)). Afterwards, they will take a memory test on the details from the videos in the assigned language for each video, in which they will be given a question ("What was the color of the glove left by the robber?), a possible answer to the question ("black"), and will be asked to say whether that answer is true or false as having happened in the prior video. 

Our hypothesis is that individuals using their foreign language (English) will be less likely to endorse false information than those using their native language (Chinese).

However, if we do get a significant Language x Order effect in our analyses, we will divide the sample in half and analyze only the first paradigm (thereby analyzing Language as a between subjects factor).

Also, prior to participating all subjects must be native Mandarin Chinese speakers who know English as a second language and are over 18 years old. This will be assessed via a prescreen before they participate in the study.

The goal of this project is to examine the likelihood that individuals will endorse remembering false information, using the misinformation effect paradigm. In this paradigm, subjects will watch two silent videos, and then receive a narrative about each which contains false details about the prior video (one in their native Chinese; one in their foreign English: each narrative will be assigned one of six native speakers within each language (6 Chinese, 6 English: 12 speakers total)). data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

other.value:
(1) We will look at correlations among responses to all dependent variables both within and across agents and vignettes. 

(2) We will look at rates of responses for our dichotomous questions and compare proportions across agents and scenarios using non-parametric tests.

(3) We will see whether participants respond to all 4 scenarios in the same way. Previously, we have found that the construction scenario also yields a main effect of power such that the person giving orders is always to blame. We will check if we find this again.   

(4) We will investigate whether demographic variables such as political orientation and self-identified social class moderate our effects.

sample.value:
We conducted an a priori power analysis, alpha set to .05, beta set to .8. We used the effect size of f=.94 from a previous version of this study in which we manipulated priority instead of consistency. We expect this study to yield a similar effect size.

This yields a target sample size of 8. We are willing to pay for more and so we will recruit 50 participants for this survey.

analyses.value:
For each scenario, we will compare attributions of blame, will to act, perceived sense of conscious will, perceived sense of control over each action, and perceived intent for both actors per scenario using a mixed ANOVA. We will calculate the Cronbach's alpha for the aforementioned DVs and if it is above .7, we will create a composite for our DV. If these items do not cohere at .7, we will do an exploratory factor analysis, and create a composite from the items that do hang together.

if all scenarios show the expected pattern, we will collapse across scenarios and run a multilevel model with our between subjects will factor, within subjects agent factor, both nested within scenario. We will model scenarios and participants as random effects.

outliers.value:
We will include a manipulation check measure on Prolific. We will run analyses both on the full sample and on only those who pass the manipulation check. If the results are comparable, we will report the full sample. If not, we will report on only those who passed. 

We will also look for indicators that participants are showing response invariance (i.e., just choosing 7 for every question) and exclude those participants as well.

dependent.value:
Our main dependent variables are: blameworthiness, will to act, perceived sense of conscious will, perceived control over each action, perceived intent, and teleological vs. mechanistic explanations of each action. All questions are on 7 point likert scales, except for one question with a dichotomous outcome, which asks whether an actor's behavior is more mechanistic or more teleological. 

Additionally, we have one question only for the agent in a position to take orders. We ask whether this agent's actions can be best explain by the higher order reason described in the scenario, or by following orders.

conditions.value:
There are four different scenarios that all participants will see (a private equity firm, an election, a building construction, and a tech company). In this study, each scenario has two versions: one in which priority, consistency, and exclusivity (PCE) of the command-order chain are maintained, and a second in which consistency is NOT maintained. This level is between subjects -- participants will only see one version of each scenario (i.e, if a participant sees the PCE version of the tech scenario, they will not see the lack of consistency version of that scenario as well). 

For each scenario presented, participants will answer DVs about two actors involved (e.g., in the private equity firm scenario, participants will answer questions about a CEO and a middle manager). This level is within subjects -- all participants will answer questions about both actors, regardless of which version of each scenario they see.

hypothesis.value:
We plan to assess how participants ascribe moral responsibility, will and intent to two actors (one who gives orders, one in a position to follow them) in a scenario in which there is a morally bad outcome.

We are interested in seeing whether responsibility is ascribed in line with Wegner's "illusion of conscious will" (2002). According to Wegner, conscious will is experienced when we infer that our thoughts have caused an action. The illusion of conscious will (perceived sense of authorship over an action) occurs when three things are maintained: (1) priority -- when a thought appears in consciousness just before an action; (2) consistency -- when the thought is consistent with the action; and (3) exclusivity -- when the thought is not accompanied with other alternative causes of the action. When these three are fulfilled, we experience conscious will and claim authorship over actions. 

We plan to extend this theory to third person ascriptions of responsibility, specifically when one person gives orders, and another is in a position to follow those orders. We theorize that this two person scenario can map onto one person's experience of will, in that the person giving the order plays the role of our conscious thoughts, and the person in a position to carry out the order is in the role of our bodies, doing the action. 

In this study we predict that greater conscious will to act and attributions of responsibility will be allocated to actors who give orders when the relationship between the order and the person who follows the order meets Wegner's criteria of having priority, consistency, and exclusivity.  Specifically, in this study we are manipulating whether the order and the action that follows are consistent with each other. We predict that when there is consistency, the person who gives the orders is perceived as more responsible. When there is a lack of consistency, the person who was in a position to follow the order will be ascribed greater responsibility.

registration_responses.name: Following Orders: Consistency

(3) We will see whether participants respond to all 4 scenarios in the same way. Previously, we have found that the construction scenario also yields a main effect of power such that the person giving orders is always to blame. We will check if we find this again.   

(4) We will investigate whether demographic variables such as political orientation and self-identified social class moderate our effects.

We are interested in seeing whether responsibility is ascribed in line with Wegner's "illusion of conscious will" (2002). attributes.title: What is a Frame? Frames as Distinct from Priming and Learning

q1.value: What is a Frame? Frames as Distinct from Priming and Learning

q5.value: I’d like to thank Seth Hill for his valuable feedback in constructing this survey, as well as Alexandra Woodruff and Nicholas Smith for their help in fielding the study.

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: • Previous research into framing effects in political science has left the mechanism behind frames underspecified. This has resulted in research that tests framing effects but incidentally creates a bundled treatment by either including a prime or persuasive information, meaning that previous estimates of framing effects are not necessarily capturing a distinct effect. Using a novel survey experiment, I build and test a new theory of framing that is distinct from priming and persuasion and tests the relative importance of this mechanism compared to previous mechanisms in producing a framing effect.

q16.value: • H1: People will infer that people from the sender’s party will weigh the framed attribute more heavily. • H2: People will update their attribute weights conditional on the frame coming from a co-partisan. • H3: When the accessibility and learning about the issue are held constant, framing effects will persist.

q17.value: • To test H1 I will look at the results of rank orders of attributes attributed to partisan. To reiterate, I expect participants to learn about a party if they are exposed to a frame from a partisan. I model this in the following way: o ImportanceAttribute = β1 ∗ FrameAttribute ∗ party + β2 ∗ Frameattribute + β3 ∗ party • To test H2, I will do a similar analysis but focused on the respondent. o importanceattribute = β1 ∗ frameattribute ∗ party + β2 ∗ frameattribute + β3 ∗ party o In this case, the analysis will be identical but party will take on a score of 1 if the frame came from a co-partisan. I expect β1 will be positive, meaning individuals update their weights conditional on receiving a frame from a co-partisan. • To test H3, I will turn to the two frame condition and run the same model. In this case, I still expect β1 to be positive. If β2 is positive, this is evidence that learning is producing some of the framing effect. If β1 is smaller in this case than in the previous analyses of the one frame condition, that is evidence that accessibility is producing some of the framing effect.

registration_responses.q1: What is a Frame? Frames as Distinct from Priming and Learning
registration_responses.q5: I’d like to thank Seth Hill for his valuable feedback in constructing this survey, as well as Alexandra Woodruff and Nicholas Smith for their help in fielding the study.

Using a novel survey experiment, I build and test a new theory of framing that is distinct from priming and persuasion and tests the relative importance of this mechanism compared to previous mechanisms in producing a framing effect.

attributes.title: Pre-Analysis Plan for Ethics of Migration \\ Updated to include new survey data

q1.value: Pre-Analysis Plan for Ethics of Migration \\ Updated to include new survey data

q2.value: Margaret E. Peters | Thania Sanchez | Yang-Yang Zhou

q5.value: This project has been funded by a grant from a NSF RAPID Grant 1638952, the Whitney and Betty MacMillan Center for International and Area Studies at Yale University, and the Center for Human Values at Princeton University., This is an update of an earlier project, registered with EGAP under the ID number 20160621AD.

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: Many normative theories on the ethics of migration conclude that countries have duties to refugees, but it is less clear how much and how far these duties go. While these norms of justice shape policies and attitudes towards refugees, as a practical matter they do not shed sufficient light on what policies should be put in place to help refugees. For example, while almost all people in Europe currently think Syrian refugees should be given some aid, there is a disagreement about what that aid should consist of. From granting temporary housing, to full citizenship rights, limiting the number of refugees, or preventing their access to state funded programs, individuals differ on their views of what they think refugees are owed by their countries. Existing studies have explored public opinion in receiving countries toward migrants, yet we know relatively little about the views of migrants themselves. To this end, this paper seeks to understand the opinions of migrants on the ethics of migration and the duties of host countries.

q16.value: Instrumental Migrant Hypothesis 1: Migrants will support illegal migration, more entrance, and more rights for migrants who are fleeing similar situations as themselves. Instrumental Migrant Hypothesis 2: Migrants will support admission (benefits) for migrants similar to themselves. Sympathetic Migrant Hypothesis: Migrants will support admission (benefits) for migrants similar to who are demed to be more worthy of sympathy. Instrumental Migrant Hypothesis 3: In general migrants will oppose any aid for no admission deals.

q17.value: In this revision to our previous PAP, we now include survey data of Venezuelan migrants in Colombia. In September-October 2019, we conducted a survey in two cities with substantial concentrations of Venezuelan migrants and internally displaced people, Cali and Cucuta, Colombia. In each city, we plan to survey about 800 Venezuelans (1600 total). Sample sizes were determined by power calculations and our available funding. A respected survey firm in Colombia (CNC) ran the face-to-face survey (under IRB protocols). We used two strategies to find Venezuelan respondents. First, we conducted a door-to-door survey in neighborhoods known to have concentrations of migrants. Enumerators randomly selected blocks as starting points and then used a skip rule between units. We were concerned that the migrants in these households were more established and wealthier so, as a second strategy, the firm created a list of places where Venezuelan gather (government offices, shelters, churches), randomly selected starting places, and then interviewed migrants they met according to a skip rule. Only Venezuelans who had move in the last three years are included and no dual nationals were included. While not a representative sample of all migrants in these cities, all attempts were made to create a high-quality convenience sample. The survey was programmed into the Qualtrics offline software application, allowing CNC to run the study without a stable Internet connection. Respondents were told that the survey was sent by researchers at XXX (redacted for anonymity) universities and received roughly $5 in compensation to complete the survey. The survey for lasted approximately one hour.

registration_responses.q1: Pre-Analysis Plan for Ethics of Migration \\ Updated to include new survey data
registration_responses.q2: Margaret E. Peters | Thania Sanchez | Yang-Yang Zhou
registration_responses.q5: This project has been funded by a grant from a NSF RAPID Grant 1638952, the Whitney and Betty MacMillan Center for International and Area Studies at Yale University, and the Center for Human Values at Princeton University., This is an update of an earlier project, registered with EGAP under the ID number 20160621AD.
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data
registration_responses.q15: Many normative theories on the ethics of migration conclude that countries have duties to refugees, but it is less clear how much and how far these duties go. While these norms of justice shape policies and attitudes towards refugees, as a practical matter they do not shed sufficient light on what policies should be put in place to help refugees. For example, while almost all people in Europe currently think Syrian refugees should be given some aid, there is a disagreement about what that aid should consist of. From granting temporary housing, to full citizenship rights, limiting the number of refugees, or preventing their access to state funded programs, individuals differ on their views of what they think refugees are owed by their countries. Existing studies have explored public opinion in receiving countries toward migrants, yet we know relatively little about the views of migrants themselves. To this end, this paper seeks to understand the opinions of migrants on the ethics of migration and the duties of host countries.
registration_responses.q16: Instrumental Migrant Hypothesis 1: Migrants will support illegal migration, more entrance, and more rights for migrants who are fleeing similar situations as themselves. Instrumental Migrant Hypothesis 2: Migrants will support admission (benefits) for migrants similar to themselves. Sympathetic Migrant Hypothesis: Migrants will support admission (benefits) for migrants similar to who are demed to be more worthy of sympathy. Instrumental Migrant Hypothesis 3: In general migrants will oppose any aid for no admission deals.
registration_responses.q17: In this revision to our previous PAP, we now include survey data of Venezuelan migrants in Colombia. In September-October 2019, we conducted a survey in two cities with substantial concentrations of Venezuelan migrants and internally displaced people, Cali and Cucuta, Colombia. In each city, we plan to survey about 800 Venezuelans (1600 total). Sample sizes were determined by power calculations and our available funding. A respected survey firm in Colombia (CNC) ran the face-to-face survey (under IRB protocols). We used two strategies to find Venezuelan respondents. First, we conducted a door-to-door survey in neighborhoods known to have concentrations of migrants. Enumerators randomly selected blocks as starting points and then used a skip rule between units. We were concerned that the migrants in these households were more established and wealthier so, as a second strategy, the firm created a list of places where Venezuelan gather (government offices, shelters, churches), randomly selected starting places, and then interviewed migrants they met according to a skip rule. Only Venezuelans who had move in the last three years are included and no dual nationals were included. While not a representative sample of all migrants in these cities, all attempts were made to create a high-quality convenience sample. The survey was programmed into the Qualtrics offline software application, allowing CNC to run the study without a stable Internet connection. Respondents were told that the survey was sent by researchers at XXX (redacted for anonymity) universities and received roughly $5 in compensation to complete the survey. The survey for lasted approximately one hour.

attributes.title: Social Media and Political Advocacy: List Experiment

q1.value: Social Media and Political Advocacy: List Experiment

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: In 2016, more than 50% of ANES respondents reported engaging in political advocacy. Political advocacy is measured by asking survey respondents if they would try to persuade someone to vote for a candidate their discussant did not support. While this communication behavior remained steady for most of the 20th Century, since 2008 there has been a marked increase. Coinciding with this increase in advocacy is the rise in social media access and usage. We will create an experiment to test the relationship between using social media and partaking in this notoriously difficult type of political communication. Based on expectations from the social networks literature, we expect that social distance will have a significant impact on one’s willingness to engage in political advocacy. Specifically, relationship between discussants—family, friends, or someone who they do not personally know—will affect the likelihood of advocating. However, the development of social media as a forum for political communication will attenuate the social costs associated with this more contentious form of political communication. As such, we theorize as social media mitigates the costs of advocacy for some relationships, while it increases the costs in others. This is the case because one may be willing to discuss and advocate for candidates online with friends, but not with family where the fear of cognitive dissonance and conflict will make these discussions more likely in face-to-face context. See EGAP pre-registration 20190516AA.

q16.value: Social Media Access Increases Advocacy H1: Across all relationships combined, the sum of advocacy will be greater for those who have social media as an option. Aggregate Advocacy by Medium H2: Comparing differences between media types, the sum of advocacy will be greater for those advocating to friends who have social media as an option than those who do not have it as an option. H3a: Comparing differences between media types, the sum of advocacy will be lower for those advocating to family who have social media as an option than those who do not have it as an option. H3b: Comparing differences between media types, the sum of advocacy will be greater for those advocating to family who have social media as an option than those who do not have it as an option. H4: Comparing differences between media types, the sum of advocacy will be greater for those advocating to strangers who have social media as an option than those who do not have it as an option. Advocacy by Relationship Social Media Conditions H5: Comparing differences between relationship types, the sum of advocacy will be less for those advocating to family who have social media as an option than those advocating on social media to friends. H6: Comparing differences between relationship types, the sum of advocacy will be less for those advocating to strangers who have social media as an option than those advocating on social media to friends. Non-Social Media Conditions H7: Comparing differences between relationship types, the sum of advocacy will be less for those advocating to family who do not have social media as an option than those advocating to friends. H8: Comparing differences between relationship types, the sum of advocacy will be less for those advocating to strangers who do not have social media as an option than those advocating to friends.

q17.value: Logistic regression models and pairwise correlational analysis.

q24.value: KSU Study 20-158: Fall 2019 POLS 1101 Student Survey

attributes.title: Informal Economy Workers and Preference for Foreign Direct Investment: Evidence from India

q1.value: Informal Economy Workers and Preference for Foreign Direct Investment: Evidence from India

q2.value: S.P. Harish | Helen Milner | Nita Rudta

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: Why are overwhelming majorities of citizens in the developing world seemingly convinced about the benefits of globalization? The general public in developing economies shows the strongest support for benefits derived from trade and foreign investment across the board. This is remarkable at a time when a backlash against globalization is brewing across so many rich democracies. Both groups of nations have been subject to many of the same distresses often associated with globalization: susceptibility to financial crises, growing inequality, increased immigration, and rising foreign competition for local firms. Many scholars have analyzed how perceptions of globalization’s ‘winners’ and ‘losers’ affect public preferences towards foreign commerce in developed economies. Yet surprisingly few have explored this question in less developed countries (LDCs), which could, in turn, shed light on the growing disenchantment with globalization in the rest of the world. In this study, we focus on support for foreign direct investment (FDI) in LDCs- primarily because FDI is relatively new phenomenon that is easily visible to the public as a marker of globalization.

q16.value: The full list of hypotheses that are tested in this study is available in the pre-analysis plan document.

q17.value: A detailed discussion of how the hypotheses will be tested is available in the pre- analysis plan document.
